question: If $R_1$ and $R_2$ are equivalence relations in a set $A$, show that $R_1 \cap R_2$ is also an equivalence relation.
solution:
Solution

Since $R_1$ and $R_2$ are equivalence relations, $(a, a) \in R_1$, and $(a, a) \in R_2 \ \forall \ a \in A$.

This implies that $(a, a) \in R_1 \cap R_2$, $\forall \ a \in A$, showing $R_1 \cap R_2$ is reflexive.

Further, $(a, b) \in R_1 \cap R_2 \Rightarrow (a, b) \in R_1$ and $(a, b) \in R_2 \Rightarrow (b, a) \in R_1$ and $(b, a) \in R_2 \Rightarrow (b, a) \in R_1 \cap R_2$, hence, $R_1 \cap R_2$ is symmetric.

Similarly, $(a, b) \in R_1 \cap R_2$ and $(b, c) \in R_1 \cap R_2 \Rightarrow (a, c) \in R_1$ and $(a, c) \in R_2$.

This shows that $R_1 \cap R_2$ is transitive.

Thus, $R_1 \cap R_2$ is an equivalence relation.
